trial_identification.studytitle: Prescribed physical Activity for people with Type 2 Diabetes: kanohi-ki-te-kanohi-support.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: New Zealand Green Prescription by face-to-face vs telephone intervention, Maori vs European for people with type 2 diabetes: effect on body weight.

interventions.interventions: The Green Prescription (GrX) programme is designed to increase the uptake of physical activity among individuals with physically-limiting medical conditions. A script (GrX) prepared by general practitioners or practice nurses is faxed to Regional Sports Trust GrX teams to typically provide advice and support around increasing physical activity and improving nutrition. In this research the GrX is delivered by a GrX kaiwhakahaere/support person based at Sport Waikato. This person helps and supports the participant to set and achieve small achieveable goals with the GrX kaiwhakahaere through contact once a month for six months. The contact time is typically less than a hour.
interventions.comparator: Participants will be randomised within ethnicity and sex (Maori or European; male or female) to receive either the kanohi-ki-te-kanohi (face-to-face) or telephone intervention. At baseline, six month and one year measurements will be made. Effectiveness of each intervention will be measured by reported uptake of physical activity, fitness, reduction in waist circumference and weight loss as well as glucose homeostasis. The outcomes will be examined in terms of treatment, ethnicity and sex. Qualitative information will undergo thematic analysis and explore attitudes, behaviours and motivational factors to physical activity uptake by ethnicity and gender in the context of quantitative outcomes. Case studies and testimonials will be used to enrich the information and triangulate the findings.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Weight loss and reduction in waist measurement. Measurements of weight (calibrated electronic scales) and waist (non-stretch tape measure)
Increased time and intensity of physical activity by questionnaire

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Identify which GRx delivery programme (kanohi-ki-te-kanohi (n=70) or telephone(n=70)) results in: greater weight and waist circumference (cm) loss
Identify which GRx delivery programme (kanohi-ki-te-kanohi or telephone) results in: greater increase in time and daily intensity of physical activity and fitness levels
Identify the strengths and weakness of the two GRx delivery programmes
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At 6 and 12 months from baseline qualitative interviews

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Identify differences in response to the approach between Maori (n=70) & NZ Europeans (n=70)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At 6 and 12 months from baseline qualitative interviews

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Maori and New Zealand European aged 18 or more diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Insulin therapy within next 12 months At risk feet including past lower limb amputations End stage renal failure Significant vascular disease People already engaging in more than 2 Â½ hours of moderate activity per week or at least 30 minutes of exercise per day

trial_design.concealment: Allocation was concealed through central randomisation by computer of scripts through the GrX team administrator. This person is not responsibile for the delivery modes of GrX or any interaction with participants in this study.
trial_design.sequence: Participants are stratified to either kanohi-ki-te-kanohi or telephone intervention by gender and ethnicity (50% Maori and 50% New Zealand Europeans).
trial_design.designfeatures: Qualitative information will undergo thematic analysis and explore attitudes, behaviours and motivational factors to physical activity uptake by ethnicity and gender in the context of quantitative outcomes. Case studies and testimonials will be used to enrich the information and triangulate the findings.

fundingsource.fundingname: Ministry of Health (formerly Sport and Recreation New Zealand (SPARC)

secondarysponsor.sponsoraddress: Brian Perry Sports House Avalon Drive PO Box 46 HAMILTON 3240

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This study seeks to evaluate for people with newly diagnosed type 2 diabetes the six month implementation of a primary care prescribed physical activity programme. A kanohi-ki-te-kanohi/face-to-face approach will be compared to the telephone approach and differences between Maori or European and male and female responses assessed through measurements of weight and waist , questionnaires and interviews at baseline, six and twelve months.

ethicscommitee.ethicaddress: 3rd floor, BNZ building 354 Victoria St PO Box 1031 Hamilton 3204
